docs.lead_paragraph: The 19 babies in the neonatal intensive care unit at New York Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn were typical of the infants in similar hospitals elsewhere. Eighteen were born weeks or months before term, defined as 37 or more weeks after the mother's last menstrual period.

headline.main: Premature Births Rise Sharply, Confounding Obstetricians

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Science Times article focuses on various aspects of rising rate of premature births in US, which have grown 27% since 1981 to more than 1,300 preterm births daily; notes that emphasis of research by National Institute of Child Health and Human Development is in finding markers to identify women likely to deliver preterm before actual labor begins; holds that, even when identified early treatments have not been fully developed to keep labor at bay; notes that tocolytic treatments can delay labor 24 to 48 hours giving physicians time to administer drugs to speed fetal lung maturation and reduce risk of brain hemorrhage; says that fetal membrane infection, multiple pregnancy, separation of placenta and stress on mother or baby are four factors that have been identified as potential tiggers of premature labor; photos (L)
docs.snippet: The 19 babies in the neonatal intensive care unit at New York Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn were typical of the infants in similar hospitals elsewhere.    Eighteen were born weeks or months before term, defined as 37 or more weeks after the mother's...

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT

docs.lead_paragraph: We hear about the miracles: the babies born weighing two pounds or less who grow up to play sports and graduate from high school, even college. But rarely do people hear the very sad stories of the thousands of tiny babies born months before their time who do not do nearly as well, who spend three months in the hospital, sometimes suffering crisis after crisis and finally emerging with lifelong sensory, mental or physical disabilities.

headline.main: Experts Strive to Make More Pregnancies Full Term

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column gives overview of factors that influence woman's ability to carry baby to full term and details what symptoms of early labor pregnant women should look for to avoid complications; factors such as maternal age, demographic background, prenatal care, body weight, pre-existing health conditions, history of premature birth and early uterine contractions can all increase risk of delivering premature baby; possible drug therapies and causes of infant mortality are charted; graph (M)
docs.snippet: We hear about the miracles: the babies born weighing two pounds or less who grow up to play sports and graduate from high school, even college.    But rarely do people hear the very sad stories of the thousands of tiny babies born months before their...

docs.lead_paragraph: Starting toilet training early is a good way to have it last longer, a study released yesterday said. When parents began intensive toilet training -- directing the child to use the toilet more than three times a day -- before the child reached 27 months, it took 10 to 16 months and ended, on average, when the child was 35 months old.
docs.abstract: Dr Nathan J Blum, Philadelphia Children's Hospital researcher, releases study in Pediatrics (journal) that shows starting toddler toilet training early means longer overall process with both early and late learners completing training around 35 or 36 months of age (S)
docs.snippet: Starting toilet training early is a good way to have it last longer, a study released yesterday said.    When parents began intensive toilet training -- directing the child to use the toilet more than three times a day -- before the child reached 27...

docs.lead_paragraph: One afternoon, I was paged to see a man who had passed out while waiting for an appointment. When I arrived, he was lying on his back, awake and looking at the nurses and medical staff bustling around him. ''Are you having chest pains?'' I asked. He looked at me directly but did not say anything. I repeated my question in Spanish and French and tapped my hands on my chest to illustrate. Still no answer.

headline.main: When a Patient Is Lost in the Translation

docs.abstract: United States 2000 census shows 19 million people nationwide have limited ability to speak and understand English language, creating potential for serious miscommunications between doctor and patient; Dr Glen Flores study in journal Pediatrics identifies high incidence of translation errors made by offical interpreters and lay persons interpreting for patients unable to understand English; research shows need for better training for interpreters and medical staff to avoid serious patient risk and potential legal issues; cartoon (M)
docs.snippet: One afternoon, I was paged to see a man who had passed out while waiting for an appointment. When I arrived, he was lying on his back, awake and looking at the nurses and medical staff bustling around him.     ''Are you having chest pains?'' I asked....

docs.lead_paragraph: A rough surface inside the shoes of athletes can help protect their feet, knees and ankles, according to a new study that involved 17 members of the Australian women's soccer team. The study, published last week in The British Journal of Sports Medicine, found that the women had a poorer sense of changes in the positions of their feet when they wore their soccer shoes than when they were barefoot, but that adding a textured insole to their shoes brought their scores back up to the barefoot level.
docs.abstract: Study involving members of Australian women's soccer team, published in British Journal of Sports Medicine, finds use of textured insoles facilitates better feel for footwork, particularly movement requiring rapid changes in pace and direction; researcher Dr Gordon Waddington of Canberra Hospital contends textured insole may also guard against injury (S)
docs.snippet: A rough surface inside the shoes of athletes can help protect their feet, knees and ankles, according to a new study that involved 17 members of the Australian women's soccer team.    The study, published last week in The British Journal of Sports...

docs.lead_paragraph: In controlling an epidemic of any new infectious disease, finding a diagnostic test is of paramount importance. So a test for the agent that causes the mysterious new respiratory ailment that is being spread in and from Asia is atop the wish list for everyone who is trying to contain the disease. Doctors believe a virus causes the disease, severe acute respiratory disease, or SARS. But they do not know for sure. And because they have no diagnostic test, they can have trouble distinguishing between patients with SARS and those who are suffering ordinary pneumonia or other respiratory complaints. A reliable test would most likely aid in the care of patients and reduce the number of people being isolated for up to three weeks because of fears they have contracted the disease.

headline.main: To Contain Ailment, a Test Heads the Wish List

docs.abstract: Dr Klaus Stohr, World Health Organization director for scientific SARS investigation, emphasizes dire need for test to detect disease; cause of SARS has not been identified and therefore accurate testing and treatment have not been developed; several preliminary tests are described and evaluated including polymerase chain reaction, which has not falsely identified virus in specimins, but sometimes fails to identify SARS when present; promising evidence supports early detection of illness in nose and mouth secretions during first five days of infection and in tears on first day of infection; photo (M)
docs.snippet: In controlling an epidemic of any new infectious disease, finding a diagnostic test is of paramount importance. So a test for the agent that causes the mysterious new respiratory ailment that is being spread in and from Asia is atop the wish list for...

docs.lead_paragraph: A new approach to Parkinson's disease has shown promising results with a small group of patients in a preliminary trial. Though not yet confirmed, the development could relieve the gloom that recently settled on the field when the technique of implanting fetal brain cells in patients proved to do some harm and not much good. Parkinson's disease develops when some unknown agent kills neurons that produce a nerve-to-nerve messenger known as dopamine, which is important in the control of movement. As the neurons die, patients develop tremors, experience spells of rigidity and may lose their sense of smell. Most patients respond well to L-dopa, which supplements the dopamine in the brain, but its effectiveness diminishes with time.

headline.main: Promising Results Are Seen In Small Parkinson's Trial

docs.abstract: Dr Clive Svendsen reports findings in Nature Medicine that show success of hormone GDNF in arresting and sometimes reversing effects of Parkinson's disease; five trial patients were given GDNF drips targeted to area of brain called putamen, known to be deficient in dopamine; group averaged 40% improvement in Parkinson's symptoms (S)
docs.snippet: A new approach to Parkinson's disease has shown promising results with a small group of patients in a preliminary trial. Though not yet confirmed, the development could relieve the gloom that recently settled on the field when the technique of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Mothers who are depressed or anxious are more likely to take their children to doctors for stomachaches and abdominal pains, a new study has concluded. The study found that mothers with the highest levels of depression were twice as likely as mothers with the lowest levels to seek medical help for abdominal pain reported by their children. The gap persisted even when the figures were adjusted to account for different levels of pain.
docs.abstract: University of Washington School of Social Work study, presented at Society of Behavioral Medicine conference, shows connection between depressed mothers and children going to doctors for stomach pain; study suggests pediatricians take into account that decision to get medical treatment for children can be influenced by mother's psychological state; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Mothers who are depressed or anxious are more likely to take their children to doctors for stomachaches and abdominal pains, a new study has concluded.     The study found that mothers with the highest levels of depression were twice as likely as...

docs.lead_paragraph: Children with chronic asthma and gastric reflux were able to cut their use of asthma medicine in half after their digestive problems were treated aggressively, a study being published today in the journal Chest has found. People with asthma are known to be more prone to gastroesophageal reflux disorder, or GERD, than the general population, though the relation between the two disorders is unclear. In the study, researchers examined 46 asthma patients, ages 5 to 10, who had no other risk factor for asthma, like allergies or a parent who smoked, and found that 27 showed signs of GERD.
docs.abstract: Dr Vikram Khoshoo, West Jefferson Medical Center (Marrero, La) researcher, has shown correlation between gastroesophageal reflux disorder (GERD) and asthma; direct connection is still unclear, but study of children with chronic asthma and symptoms of GERD showed agressive treatment of GERD significantly reduced need for asthma medication; cartoon (S)
